It's perfectly acceptable to be retarded, but being antagonistic over a centered dock is just flat out brainrot. I questioned your advice, I didn't take it personally. It was you being pointlessly antagonistic which has kept this going on.

>Opinions are subjective
And user interface guidelines are not.
Which is why taskbars are inefficient. They cover too much of the screen without any clear purpose, and screen real estate should always be the focus of good desktops. Notice how docks increase in size the more shortcuts you add? And shrink when you remove shortcuts? That's because a key part of user interface design is being minimal, unobstrusive, and focused (which uncentered panels and uncentered docks do not provide). Centered icons provide simple recognition which does not force the user to recall where they put the dock. The symmetrical layout provides focus.

There is a big difference between simply preferring something, and being a stuck up bitch about your poor advice. You just didn't know what you were talking about.

>>90412333
How do you set gif as wallpaper? Any advice?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90415320
This thing is in my bspwm config. To run it on start with a good speed:
"/home/anon/.config/scripts/bgfehgif.sh 0.1 /home/anon/Pictures/bg1.gif &"

That thing is "bgfehgif.sh" file. It makes pieces from gif and changes it with feh I guess. That won't eat much of CPU or GPU speed as other things running gifs as wallpaper:
<code>
#!/bin/env bash
select1='feh --bg-fill --no-fehbg '
select2='xwallpaper --zoom '
select3='xloadimage -onroot -fullscreen '
select4='xfconf-query -c xfce4-desktop -p /backdrop/screen0/monitor0/workspace0/last-image -s '
select5='hsetroot -full '
select6='gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.background picture-uri file:///'

prog=$select1
[ "$#" -lt "1" ] || [ "$#" -gt "2" ] && { echo -e "ERROR : args number invalid \n $0 speed /path/name.gif" ; echo "try 0.010 as speed" ; exit 1 ; }
dir=/tmp/bgfehgif
#example of speed : 0.010
speed=$1
name=$2

[[ "$name" == "" ]] && { name=$speed ; speed=${name##*-} ; }

[ ! -f "$name" ] && { echo "file not found" ; exit 1 ; }
[ -f "/usr/local/share/gif-wallpaper/loading.png" ] && ${select1}/usr/local/share/gif-wallpaper/loading.png
hash=`md5sum $name | cut -f1 -d" "`

[[ ! -d $dir ]] && mkdir $dir

[[ ! -d $dir/$hash ]] && { mkdir $dir/$hash ; echo "spliting .." ; convert -coalesce $name $dir/$hash/$hash.png ; echo ok ; }

if [ "$1" == "auto" ]; then
frames=($(ls -v "$dir/$hash"))
amount_of_frames=${#frames[@]}
frames_per_second=30
speed=$(bc <<< "scale=3; ($amount_of_frames/$frames_per_second) * (1/$frames_per_second)")
fi

while : ; do for i in ` ls $dir/$hash -v ` ; do $prog$dir/$hash/$i ; sleep $speed ; done ; done
</code>


P.S.: Don't forget to install feh itself. "sudo apt-get install feh", "sudo pacman -S feh", "sudo emerge --ask feh" or smthn like dat. If anything else will be required, I guess it will tell you it can't find it. Good luck!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90415501
just create a file with things inside of <code></code> Name it gifbg.sh.
I hope U'r not afraid of terminals. Just open it.
1) "mv gifbg.sh ~/.config/." # to move it somewhere closer to where it should be
2) "sudo chmod +x ~/.config/gifbg.sh" # to make it executable
3) "~/.config/gifbg.sh 0.1 %PATH%" # to run it. For test. Change %PATH% with path to image. Smthn like "~/Pictures/bg1.gif"
4) create file ~/.config/autostart/gifbg" and put next things in it:
[Desktop Entry]
Encoding=UTF-8
Version=0.1
Type=Application
Name=Gifbg
Comment=Gif background
Exec=/home/%USERNAME%/.config/gifbg.sh
OnlyShowIn=XFCE;
StartupNotify=false
Terminal=false
Hidden=false

Change %USERNAME% with your username.
Then (after step 4) it should run itself on startup. If it doesn't, find a way to run a shell script on startup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90436474
Not unless you think having the central config files to rebuild your systems from is really, really cool. I've been using it for a few years now and for the most part it works fine, but every now and then there's something that's just broken. Usually it will run if you put a compatibility layer called steam-run first in the command, but sometimes even that doesn't help in which case you can't just compile from source normally, you need to actually write a package declaration for the package manager and install it that way.

I struggle through because I think NixOS is really cool, but it's definitely more difficult than something like Arch and for very little benefit. Does have some nice features, for example I have one computername.nix file for each of my machines, which has a different include list, which all pull from the same folder on my NAS. For example the machine I'm using as NAS doesn't pull in software.nix or display.nix, and my laptop and desktop won't pull in wireguard-server.nix and nas-server.nix, but they do instead get wireguard-client.nix and nas-client.nix. For example when I replaced alsa with pipewire, I only needed to make the change once, in a file I creatively called audio.nix, and then make sure it worked on one of my machines. Then I just included that file on the other machines, did a nixos-rebuild, and nix took care of fiddling with the configs for me.

It's basically got two use cases. You're packaging software and want to be sure you have all the includes done right (in which case there are quicker solutions that don't involve a distro hop and one of the harshest learning curve distros around), or you're maintaining a lot of machines and want the convenience of pushing both software and config updates with a single command, which I guess is very slightly the camp I'm in.

If it doesn't sound exactly perfect for you, stay away from it. It's a pain, the documentation sucks, and the forum is useless for getting explanations.

Appimages arent really any different than just putting all .so file dependencies in a directory. AppImages require you to build your application in an ancient version of centOS, which doesn't support modern c++ for example. The appimage will also depend on your system glibc which might not work. It also depends on older less secure version. Some things such as graphics drivers or opengl is not part of the appimage either so you may be required to install things outside the appimage and those driver versions might be too old.

posts.sub: Learning a programming language properly for once
posts.com:
I have been programming for several years now. It started when I was about 12 and I am still on it. The problem is that I never finished a single project, ever, at all, neither did I learn a single programming language properly. I have tried out everything pretty much to a certain degree. Python, Lua, Ruby, PHP, C99, Java, Posix Shell scripting, Javascript, C#, Scheme LISP. I tried web development (backend and frontend), game programming (writing mods and stand-alone games, at least I tried to do so), shell scripting, mobile apps and so on. OOP, functional programming, even logic programming (Stuff like Prolog), all of it. Nothing got me any results at all, after a lot of years of doing so. I am very interested in it and I do not want to drop it, but I want to start of again from scratch.
I am going to do the code of advent, even though I am pretty late on it, in the language you recommend me and do everything in it. I have read SICP and I happen to like the simplicity of Scheme, but other LISP dialects too. LISP is great, but I feel like it isn't a good language to start with, no matter the implementation. The language should be general-purpose, as I want to get really good at it, so I have at least one language I know properly. Scripting languages like Python, Lua, Ruby and Perl are fine too. I think the JVM is great. Generally I like functional programming more than OOP, but I would program in an OOP language too if it was good.

So, what language should I go with?

>>90440014
There are no FSF approved distros on your chart.
Debian, Gentoo and Void allow disabling nonfree repos, but they still ship installation instructions for nonfree software
Mint allows disabling nonfree repos too but it installs some nonfree software by default, so it could go lower if I felt like it.
Void could go higher but I've had a bad experience with it.

All other distros ship nonfree software baked into the kernel (Arch for example)
and even worse, some of them have proprietary applications preinstalled (Manjaro had Vivaldi or chrome as far as I remember)
They wouldn't be in the absolutely proprietary tier if they at least offered the option of disabling nonfree channels.

>manjaro has sane defaults
True, but that doesn't change the fact that it uses the Arch repos. Those repos ship a blobbed kernel and proprietary software, so all Arch distros should go into absolutely proprietary tier.
Oh, did you know Manjaro actually uses a mirror of the arch repos that is delayed by a week? Well that actually just makes it worse because no one accounts for this and it is essentially a cope for having an outdated mirror.
>letting people use their favorite desktop le bad
All good distros should let you pick your DE, frankly Mint and Debian do it
It's not an issue though because you can install any DE on any distro. Nothing is stopping you.

>tinkering le bad
As for this, I agree. But the fact is that Arch requires no tinkering. It just works.
You simply mount a partition, pacstrap KDE, grub, linux and dhcpcd, chroot, enable SDDM and dhcpcd in systemd, run grub-install and grub-mkconfig, set the password, exit, and reboot.

Interesting. HOW you organize the artists in your prompt radically changes how your prompt looks.
For example "by artist 1, by artist 2, by artist 3", "artist 1 artist 2 artist 3", and "Artist 1 and Artist 2 and Artist 3" will all look radically different, even though you're using the same three artists in all versions of the prompt.

>>90447562
see voldy guide
If you get a green/black screen instead of generated pictures, you have a card that doesn't support half precision floating point numbers (known problem on 16xx cards):
You must use --precision full --no-half in addition to other flags, and the model will take much more space in VRAM
If you are using a .vae file, you must also add --no-half-vae

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90445354
Training requires huge amounts of VRAM, so there's limits to what you can accomplish even with a 4090 despite its processing power. These huge AI training projects are done with 40gb and now 80gb cards, and even then VRAM is a limiting factor. You can get around this to some extent with Vega or CDNA GPUs, but those are extremely expensive (in the case of the high end cards), slow (in the case of the old Vega cards), inconvenient (most AI researchers are experienced with CUDA and not ROCm), and are mostly a bandaid on the problem rather than a solution (since they only go up to 64GB of VRAM and can use more than that by paging to system memory).

>Can it be run on old mining rigs?
I'm a former miningfag that converted his farm to an anime booba printing factory. the answer is not easily, no.
>many cards that were cost effective at mining ETH are simply not practical options for training models due to lack of VRAM (1660 supers, etc...)
>tons of mining rigs are heterogeneous in nature, many even mixed nvidia-amd ghetto rigs. during the great chip shortage you couldn't be that picky. maybe there's a way to do distributed training across cards with different VRAM and architectures but I'd expect it to be a huge pain in the ass to set up.
>mining rigs typically use cheap PCI-E 1X risers since fast GPU-CPU and GPU-GPU communication doesn't matter. for training I'd expect it to be much more important.
it's not hard to convert mining rigs to do inference at scale though, I've done it for stable diffusion and I'm printing more anime booba than I know what to do with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Improvements in image processing have simply made it easier to get visually appealing lenses out of objectively worse lenses. Optics have also improved. Photography is increasingly consumed on 6" screens where the difference between a cellphone camera and even a full frame camera can be pretty subtle. Some phones released in recent years have literally been competitive with dedicated high speed cameras in terms of value because of how much more powerful the processors are on a smartphone compared to a camera.

They're not really designed to replace a professional camera though, I know people who do video for a living and their cameras are rigged up with various bits of computer gear, displays, microphones, stabilisers, and so on. It's like comparing a raspberry pi to a thread ripper workstation and declaring them to be equal because both can beat humans at chess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90440843
They're two completely different types of virtualization.

LXC is a container, meaning it runs using the host OS. They're very lightweight, quick to create, quick to boot, and require less resources than a KVM machine. You can modify their configuration and most of the time the changes will be immediately reflected in the container. Their lightweight nature makes backups quicker and smaller since you're only backing up the relevant data rather than the entire OS install.

KVM is a traditional VM. A KVM machine is completely isolated from the host OS, which is sometimes what you want. For example, GPU passthrough to a LXC container requires the same Nvidia drivers on both the host and container. It's a pain in the ass to align two completely different systems like this. A KVM VM machine would work much better.

In my experience, a container works best in almost every situation.

>>90440913
Firewall rules. Much easier and more reliable to set the firewall for a VM through Proxmox than it is to mess with firewalls on a local system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90433412
>The Calamares installer insists on installing the bootloader on the same drive as Windows
This doesn't sound right, but assuming it is just unplug the drive for the installation or disable it in your BIOS.
>Will I still be able to select Windows Boot Manager in UEFI to get around a non-functional GRUB
EFI boot loaders are separate directories on the same filesystem. Your BIOS will have a hotkey to let you select a different one at boot, like F8 on Asus. A booted OS can overwrite the EFI filesystem and render others unbootable, as Windows does sometimes during feature upgrades, but the boot loaders don't normally interfere with each other.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90445711
dwm's "tabs" are officially called "tags" and you can just use them exactly the same like on i3 (and possibly sway, I haven't used it), BUT they're kind of more extensible than i3 workspaces.

on i3 you can have N windows assigned to every tab (N:1), but on dwm you can have N windows assigned to M tabs (N:M)

so for example you could have a browser opened on tabs 1 and 2, terminal on tab 1, and vim on tab 2
and the result would be that you'd have the first tab with (browser,terminal) and the second tab with (browser,vim)

The problem with Ranma is that it used SD 1.5 as a base.
To get good results you can't use nai or anything style prompts, you have to use SD style full descriptors like: 80sanimestyle portrait of a girl, blue hair, etc.
Or, use interrogate on a real picture first then use that as your prompt.
You can't use a bunch of boorou tags, you won't get good results.
